content:
=== Game Rules ===
Game rules in natural language:
Below is an analysis of the game based on its rules:

1. Game Genre and Look:
 • It’s clearly an action–puzzle platformer with exploration elements reminiscent of Spelunky. The visual style uses retro “tile‐based” sprites (walls, dirt blocks, boulders, diamonds, etc.) along with a protagonist (the avatar) and various enemies.
 • The level is laid out as a grid with walls, dirt floors, obstacles (boulders), collectible diamonds, a sword for attacking, and an exit door. There’s a mix of static elements (walls, dirt) and dynamic ones (falling boulders, randomly moving enemies).

2. Core Mechanics:
 • Movement and Interaction: The avatar (player character) can move around, “shoot” using its sword (or pickaxe-like tool) and interact with the environment. The avatar is set up to use the sword to “kill” or clear objects.
 • Obstacles & Environment: The level contains walls and dirt that the avatar can clear with the proper tool. Boulders act like missiles falling downward that may harm the avatar if they fall from above. They also “step back” when they meet other specific obstacles, behaving as moving hazards.
 • Enemies and Transformations: Random enemies roam the level. Additional enemy types (crabs and butterflies) interact with each other—if a crab meets a butterfly, one of them can be “killed” or even transformed into a diamond (which also gives points). This mix adds both risk and opportunities for bonus collection.
 • Resources: Diamonds are collectible resources. Colliding with them gives points, and there’s a limited stock available (up to 10 per level).
 • Special Tools: The sword (which appears only singularly and flickers) is used by the avatar to destroy certain blocks (or “kill sprites”)—for example, it’s effective against dirt.

3. Objective and Win/Loss Conditions:
 • Primary Objective: The level is completed (winning) when the exit door is “eliminated” (SpriteCounter for exitdoor reaches 0). The exit door isn’t just a simple endpoint—it requires the avatar to meet a specific condition in its interaction.
 • Unlocking the Exit: There’s a rule “exitdoor avatar > killIfOtherHasMore resource=diamond limit=9” which implies that when the avatar touches the door, the door will “kill” (or disable) the avatar if the avatar is carrying more than 9 diamonds. In practice, this means you must manage how many diamonds you have (or possibly have exactly the right number) before exiting. It forces the player to think about resource collection.
 • Losing: The game ends in loss if the avatar is eliminated (SpriteCounter for avatar reaches 0). Getting hit by hazards like falling boulders (when the avatar is underneath) or bad enemy interactions can lead to death and a game over.

4. Overall Strategy:
 • Careful Navigation: Because the level is full of hazards such as falling boulders and roaming enemies, take your time to examine the layout. Plan moves ahead to avoid being crushed or caught by enemy movements.
 • Effective Use of the Sword: Use your sword (or tool) to clear obstacles like dirt, opening paths or even eliminating enemies. But remember, you only have one at a time, so use it wisely.
 • Resource Management: Collect diamonds to boost your score but be aware of the exit door’s rule. Make sure you don’t overcollect—if you have more than 9 diamonds when you try to exit, you risk being “killed” by the door, so aim for the sweet spot.
 • Exploit Enemy Interactions: Notice that butterflies and crabs interact in a way that can transform one into a diamond (with an extra score bonus). You might be able to trigger these interactions to get additional resources or to clear the area of dangerous foes.
 • Stay Alert for Hazard Reactions: Know that objects like boulders “step back” when they run into walls, dirt, or even other boulders. Use this predictable behavior to your advantage by luring them away from your path or timing your movements to avoid being hit.
 • Balance Offense and Caution: While eliminating obstacles and enemies is key to opening the level, always be mindful of the consequences (like score deductions or accidental deaths from falling boulders). Your best play is one that carefully weighs risks and rewards.

In summary, this game challenges you to navigate a hazardous, puzzle-like platform level; use your limited resources (like the sword) smartly; collect and manage diamonds to boost your score without “overloading” the exit condition; and exploit enemy interactions to your advantage. With careful planning, precise movement, and smart resource management, you can clear the level and win the game.

You are an intelligent player playing a video game, and you have a friend provide you strategy. Interpret the state, rule, strategy and act accordingly. Notice that your avatar position is one of the most important information, if the position doesn't change from the last state, you need to analyze the state and make a different action from the last time.

=== Available Actions ===
0: ACTION_NIL
1: ACTION_USE
2: ACTION_LEFT
3: ACTION_RIGHT
4: ACTION_DOWN
5: ACTION_UP

=== Important Mechanics Notice ===
 In some games, directional actions (LEFT, RIGHT, UP, DOWN) may first cause the avatar to rotate toward the intended direction without immediately moving. If the avatar's position does not change after a directional action, it may indicate a rotation has occurred. To proceed, you must apply the directional action again after rotation. Always verify whether the avatar actually moved after each action. Please understand the rule and the interaction set first, then locate the item, finally choose a meaningful action towards the win and respond in the format: ``` Action:<action number> ```. Include one sentence of feedback on the action and your expectation to see if it aligns with the strategy. Notice, Action 0 will not reasult in any change in this game environment, and you may need to understand the level layout first to play the game.

Action:1

I'm using the sword again—focusing it toward the exit door zone—to clear any obstructing dirt or enemy sprites near the door, which should secure our path for a safe exit while keeping our diamond count within limits.

===Long-term Plan===
```**sword strategy: Currently unarmed, the avatar lacks the means to efficiently clear obstacles. Regaining the sword is essential. Methodically maneuver within the nearby area to reestablish possession of the sword, then batch-clear dirt and enemy sprites around the exitdoor while regulating diamond count to meet exit conditions** without **Alert**```

Action:2

I'm moving left from (11,19) to (11,18), where the sword was previously located; by doing so I expect to reestablish possession of the sword, which is crucial for clearing obstacles near the exit door as planned.
